Description: Terracotta figure of Harpokrates. Much of a seated god, probably Harpokrates, with his head shaven except for a side-lock. He is naked and has a huge phallus extending beyond his knees. At his left side, his lowered left hand rests on his thigh; the right arm is raised with the palm out-turned; the side-lock curves into the back of the hand. Solid; apparently made in a two-piece or multiple mould, with much paring subsequent to the moulding. Brown Nile silt with some mica and a grey core; the surface is a matt red colour that may be a thin slip, but there appears to be additional post-firing red paint in several areas, in one case laid over a minute speck of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Ede n.d.a: 170, lot 7, dated first century bc/ad. Near: Adriani 1952: pl. xxv:4 and 6, from a favissa at Ras el-Soda, Alexandria, dated Ptolemaic period, perhaps third to second century bc. Bibliog. Franks n.d.: m 87; Fischer 1994: 260, no. 560 and Fischer 1995: 311n. 22 (pre- Hellenistic date suggested).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3035)
Condition: The scar of the block on which he sat remains, and both legs are lost below the knee; there is slight damage to the right arm and hand.
